awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Biology, Chemistry, and Physics of Xylem Surfactants
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists first proposed in 1895 that water transport in plants often occurs under negative pressure, which is generated though surface tension in the cell walls of leaves and which causes water to flow from the soil into the roots and as sap up towards the leaves. Much evidence has accumulated since then to support this hypothesis, known as the cohesion-tension theory, but it is still unknown how plants can move water under negative pressure without constantly creating bubbles in their hydraulic system, the xylem. The question how negative pressure transport works in plants has achieved new urgency with the recent discovery of surfactants in the sap. This finding contradicted the assumption that sap is essentially pure water, and that the high surface tension of water prevents bubbles from forming or from entering the hydraulic system through small pores in xylem walls. This research will determine the chemical composition of xylem surfactants, characterize their physical properties, including surface tension, locate surfactant micelles and their cellular origin in the xylem, and survey a number of plant species from different evolutionary backgrounds to determine if xylem surfactants are ubiquitous in vascular plants. Broader impacts of the project include involvement of several undergraduate and graduate students in the research, including many from groups underrepresented in science. The research has the potential to result in biomimetic applications, such as solar-powered microfluidic devices that transport liquids under negative pressure.

Previous findings have shown that xylem sap of woody angiosperms contains insoluble surfactants, including numerous proteins, glycoproteins, and phospholipids. The proposed research is motivated by a new hypothesis that insoluble surfactants enable water transport under negative pressure by controlling bubble sizes to remain smaller than a critical threshold size, below which bubbles do not expand to form embolisms. Such a mechanism could explain how it is possible to transport large amounts of gas-saturated or super-saturated water under normal, non-stressed conditions, down to several MPa of negative pressure, a feat that human engineers have been unable to replicate. The aim of the research is to characterize xylem surfactants and determine how common they are in vascular plants, including angiosperms and gymnosperms, because this information is needed before any hypotheses about their functions in plants can be tested. Methods will include lipidomic and proteomic studies of xylem sap, constrained drop surfactometry of xylem surfactants, and electron microscopy of xylem sap and xylem to locate surfactant micelles and their origin in the xylem.

por.por_cntn:
Vascular plants transport water in their hydraulic system, the xylem, under subatmospheric or negative pressure. A widely accepted axiom of xylem biology states that it is the high surface tension of water that protects xylem conduits against bubble entry through the nanopores of pit membranes that connect conduits to each other. This axiom was recently challenged by findings that xylem sap contains significant amounts of surface-active phospholipids and proteins, that surfactants isolated from xylem sap had strongly area-dependent surface tension that reached values much lower than that of water, and that xylem sap contains surfactant-coated nanobubbles. In response to these findings it has been hypothesized that xylem surfactants function to reduce bubble sizes by lowering surface tension at gas-water interfaces, and that the resulting nanobubbles remain stable below a critical threshold radius for bubbles in water, which would allow them to dissolve instead of expanding and forming embolisms. This would mean that xylem surfactants may be an essential tool that makes water transport under negative pressure possible. The research conducted with funding from this grant addressed the following questions: (1.) What is the chemical composition of xylem surfactants, including lipids, proteins, and glycoproteins? (2.) Where in the xylem are surfactants located, and where do they originate? (3.) What are the physical characteristics of xylem surfactants? (4.) Are xylem surfactants ubiquitous in vascular plants? 

Xylem surfactants extracted from seven plant species from across the phylogeny of flowering plants were found to consist mainly of phospholipids and galactolipids in various proportions. These lipids were found to coat all vessel surfaces and were especially concentrated in pit chambers and on pit membranes between vessels. The hypothesis that these lipids originate from living cells that are associated with vessels was not supported but could also not be rejected. They may mostly originate from the original living cell content of the vessels, and further research will be required to determine their origins. Xylem lipids were found to possess dynamic surface tension, meaning that they lower surface tension to about a third that of water when concentrated on a gas-water interphase, with increasing surface tension as lipid layers are stretched out over larger surface areas. This finding would have important implications for the behavior of expanding or contracting gas bubbles in xylem sap. Xylem surfactants were ubiquitous in all flowering plants (angiosperms) tested and via transmission electron microscopy were also found in xylem of gymnosperms and ferns, and even in the water-conducting hydroid cells of mosses. Thus, they appear to be ubiquitous in vascular plants.

Taken together, these findings provide a new perspective on water transport under negative pressure in vascular plants and disprove the previous assumption that xylem sap has the same surface tension as water. The presence of lipids in xylem sap also has potential implications for xylem sap viscosity and the interaction of xylem sap with surfaces inside the xylem, as it can no longer be assumed that sap has the any of the properties of pure water. The ubiquity of xylem lipids in all plant species tested proves that these lipids are compatible with water transport under negative pressure via the cohesion-tension mechanism and strongly suggests that these lipids may be required for water transport under negative pressure in plants.

At the time of this report, the findings from the research were published in three papers in peer-reviewed scientific journals and one conference proceedings paper and communicated in numerous presentations at national and international scientific meetings. Most of the research was carried out at Cal State Fullerton (CSUF), a predominantly undergraduate, minority-, and Hispanic-serving institution, and several undergraduate and graduate students, including many from groups underrepresented in science were very actively involved. The research bridged the fields of biology and chemical engineering. It has the potential to result in future biomimetic applications, such as protecting microfluidic systems that operate under negative pressure against cavitation.
